description:
Aurantiacibacter flavus is a species of bacteria that belongs to the family Cytophagaceae. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. The cells of A. flavus are typically rod-shaped and exhibit a distinctive yellow or orange pigmentation, which is attributed to the production of carotenoid compounds.

This bacterium was first isolated from soil samples and is known to be found in various environmental habitats, including soil, water, and sediments. A. flavus is considered a chemoorganotrophic organism, meaning it derives its energy and carbon from organic compounds.

Phylogenetically, A. flavus is closely related to other members of the genus Aurantiacibacter, which are known for their ability to degrade complex organic matter and participate in nutrient cycling in various ecosystems.

The physiological and metabolic capabilities of A. flavus are still under investigation, but the species is believed to play a role in the decomposition of organic matter and the transformation of nutrients in the environments where it is found.
